15#ifndef ISC_FILE_H
16#define ISC_FILE_H 1
17
18/*! \file isc/file.h */
19
20#include <stdbool.h>
21#include <stdio.h>
22
23#include <isc/lang.h>
24#include <isc/stat.h>
25#include <isc/types.h>

27ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
28
29isc_result_t
30isc_file_settime(const char *file, isc_time_t *time);
31
32isc_result_t
33isc_file_mode(const char *file, mode_t *modep);
34
35isc_result_t
36isc_file_getmodtime(const char *file, isc_time_t *time);
37/*!<
38 * \brief Get the time of last modification of a file.
39 *
40 * Notes:
41 *\li The time that is set is relative to the (OS-specific) epoch, as are
42 * all isc_time_t structures.
43 *
44 * Requires:
45 *\li file != NULL.
46 *\li time != NULL.
47 *
48 * Ensures:
49 *\li If the file could not be accessed, 'time' is unchanged.
50 *
51 * Returns:
52 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
53 * Success.
54 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND
55 * No such file exists.
56 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
57 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
58 *\li #ISC_R_NOPERM
59 * The file's metainformation could not be retrieved because
60 * permission was denied to some part of the file's path.
61 *\li #ISC_R_IOERROR
62 * Hardware error interacting with the filesystem.
63 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
64 * Something totally unexpected happened.
65 *
66 */
67
68isc_result_t
69isc_file_mktemplate(const char *path, char *buf, size_t buflen);
70/*!<
71 * \brief Generate a template string suitable for use with isc_file_openunique().
72 *
73 * Notes:
74 *\li This function is intended to make creating temporary files
75 * portable between different operating systems.
76 *
77 *\li The path is prepended to an implementation-defined string and
78 * placed into buf. The string has no path characters in it,
79 * and its maximum length is 14 characters plus a NUL. Thus
80 * buflen should be at least strlen(path) + 15 characters or
81 * an error will be returned.
82 *
83 * Requires:
84 *\li buf != NULL.
85 *
86 * Ensures:
87 *\li If result == #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
88 * buf contains a string suitable for use as the template argument
89 * to isc_file_openunique().
90 *
91 *\li If result != #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
92 * buf is unchanged.
93 *
94 * Returns:
95 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success.
96 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE buflen indicates buf is too small for the catenation
97 * of the path with the internal template string.
98 */
99
100isc_result_t
101isc_file_openunique(char *templet, FILE **fp);
102isc_result_t
103isc_file_openuniqueprivate(char *templet, FILE **fp);
104isc_result_t
105isc_file_openuniquemode(char *templet, int mode, FILE **fp);
106isc_result_t
107isc_file_bopenunique(char *templet, FILE **fp);
108isc_result_t
109isc_file_bopenuniqueprivate(char *templet, FILE **fp);
110isc_result_t
111isc_file_bopenuniquemode(char *templet, int mode, FILE **fp);
112/*!<
113 * \brief Create and open a file with a unique name based on 'templet'.
114 * isc_file_bopen*() open the file in binary mode in Windows.
115 * isc_file_open*() open the file in text mode in Windows.
116 *
117 * Notes:
118 *\li 'template' is a reserved work in C++. If you want to complain
119 * about the spelling of 'templet', first look it up in the
120 * Merriam-Webster English dictionary. (http://www.m-w.com/)
121 *
122 *\li This function works by using the template to generate file names.
123 * The template must be a writable string, as it is modified in place.
124 * Trailing X characters in the file name (full file name on Unix,
125 * basename on Win32 -- eg, tmp-XXXXXX vs XXXXXX.tmp, respectively)
126 * are replaced with ASCII characters until a non-existent filename
127 * is found. If the template does not include pathname information,
128 * the files in the working directory of the program are searched.
129 *
130 *\li isc_file_mktemplate is a good, portable way to get a template.
131 *
132 * Requires:
133 *\li 'fp' is non-NULL and '*fp' is NULL.
134 *
135 *\li 'template' is non-NULL, and of a form suitable for use by
136 * the system as described above.
137 *
138 * Ensures:
139 *\li If result is #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
140 * *fp points to an stream opening in stdio's "w+" mode.
141 *
142 *\li If result is not #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
143 * *fp is NULL.
144 *
145 * No file is open. Even if one was created (but unable
146 * to be reopened as a stdio FILE pointer) then it has been
147 * removed.
148 *
149 *\li This function does *not* ensure that the template string has not been
150 * modified, even if the operation was unsuccessful.
151 *
152 * Returns:
153 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
154 * Success.
155 *\li #ISC_R_EXISTS
156 * No file with a unique name could be created based on the
157 * template.
158 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
159 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
160 *\li #ISC_R_NOPERM
161 * The file could not be created because permission was denied
162 * to some part of the file's path.
163 *\li #ISC_R_IOERROR
164 * Hardware error interacting with the filesystem.
165 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
166 * Something totally unexpected happened.
167 */
168
169isc_result_t
170isc_file_remove(const char *filename);
171/*!<
172 * \brief Remove the file named by 'filename'.
173 */
174
175isc_result_t
176isc_file_rename(const char *oldname, const char *newname);
177/*!<
178 * \brief Rename the file 'oldname' to 'newname'.
179 */
180
181bool
182isc_file_exists(const char *pathname);
183/*!<
184 * \brief Return #true if the calling process can tell that the given file exists.
185 * Will not return true if the calling process has insufficient privileges
186 * to search the entire path.
187 */
188
189bool
190isc_file_isabsolute(const char *filename);
191/*!<
192 * \brief Return #true if the given file name is absolute.
193 */
194
195isc_result_t
196isc_file_isplainfile(const char *name);
197
198isc_result_t
199isc_file_isplainfilefd(int fd);
200/*!<
201 * \brief Check that the file is a plain file
202 *
203 * Returns:
204 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
205 * Success. The file is a plain file.
206 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
207 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
208 *\li #ISC_R_FILENOTFOUND
209 * The file does not exist. This return code comes from
210 * errno=ENOENT when stat returns -1. This code is mentioned
211 * here, because in logconf.c, it is the one rcode that is
212 * permitted in addition to ISC_R_SUCCESS. This is done since
213 * the next call in logconf.c is to isc_stdio_open(), which
214 * will create the file if it can.
215 *\li other ISC_R_* errors translated from errno
216 * These occur when stat returns -1 and an errno.
217 */
218
219isc_result_t
220isc_file_isdirectory(const char *name);
221/*!<
222 * \brief Check that 'name' exists and is a directory.
223 *
224 * Returns:
225 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
226 * Success, file is a directory.
227 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
228 * File is not a directory.
229 *\li #ISC_R_FILENOTFOUND
230 * File does not exist.
231 *\li other ISC_R_* errors translated from errno
232 * These occur when stat returns -1 and an errno.
233 */
234
235bool
236isc_file_iscurrentdir(const char *filename);
237/*!<
238 * \brief Return #true if the given file name is the current directory (".").
239 */
240
241bool
242isc_file_ischdiridempotent(const char *filename);
243/*%<
244 * Return #true if calling chdir(filename) multiple times will give
245 * the same result as calling it once.
246 */
247
248const char *
249isc_file_basename(const char *filename);
250/*%<
251 * Return the final component of the path in the file name.
252 */
253
254isc_result_t
255isc_file_progname(const char *filename, char *buf, size_t buflen);
256/*!<
257 * \brief Given an operating system specific file name "filename"
258 * referring to a program, return the canonical program name.
259 *
260 * Any directory prefix or executable file name extension (if
261 * used on the OS in case) is stripped. On systems where program
262 * names are case insensitive, the name is canonicalized to all
263 * lower case. The name is written to 'buf', an array of 'buflen'
264 * chars, and null terminated.
265 *
266 * Returns:
267 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
268 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE The name did not fit in 'buf'.
269 */
270
271isc_result_t
272isc_file_template(const char *path, const char *templet, char *buf,
273 size_t buflen);
274/*%<
275 * Create an OS specific template using 'path' to define the directory
276 * 'templet' to describe the filename and store the result in 'buf'
277 * such that path can be renamed to buf atomically.
278 */
279
280isc_result_t
281isc_file_renameunique(const char *file, char *templet);
282/*%<
283 * Rename 'file' using 'templet' as a template for the new file name.
284 */
285
286isc_result_t
287isc_file_absolutepath(const char *filename, char *path, size_t pathlen);
288/*%<
289 * Given a file name, return the fully qualified path to the file.
290 */
291
292/*
293 * XXX We should also have a isc_file_writeeopen() function
294 * for safely open a file in a publicly writable directory
295 * (see write_open() in BIND 8's ns_config.c).
296 */
297
298isc_result_t
299isc_file_truncate(const char *filename, isc_offset_t size);
300/*%<
301 * Truncate/extend the file specified to 'size' bytes.
302 */
303
304isc_result_t
305isc_file_safecreate(const char *filename, FILE **fp);
306/*%<
307 * Open 'filename' for writing, truncating if necessary. Ensure that
308 * if it existed it was a normal file. If creating the file, ensure
309 * that only the owner can read/write it.
310 */
311
312isc_result_t
313isc_file_splitpath(isc_mem_t *mctx, const char *path,
314 char **dirname, char const **basename);
315/*%<
316 * Split a path into dirname and basename. If 'path' contains no slash
317 * (or, on windows, backslash), then '*dirname' is set to ".".
318 *
319 * Allocates memory for '*dirname', which can be freed with isc_mem_free().
320 *
321 * Returns:
322 * - ISC_R_SUCCESS on success
323 * - ISC_R_INVALIDFILE if 'path' is empty or ends with '/'
324 * - ISC_R_NOMEMORY if unable to allocate memory
325 */
326
327isc_result_t
328isc_file_getsize(const char *file, off_t *size);
329/*%<
330 * Return the size of the file (stored in the parameter pointed
331 * to by 'size') in bytes.
332 *
333 * Returns:
334 * - ISC_R_SUCCESS on success
335 */
336
337isc_result_t
338isc_file_getsizefd(int fd, off_t *size);
339/*%<
340 * Return the size of the file (stored in the parameter pointed
341 * to by 'size') in bytes.
342 *
343 * Returns:
344 * - ISC_R_SUCCESS on success
345 */
346
347void *
348isc_file_mmap(void *addr, size_t len, int prot,
349 int flags, int fd, off_t offset);
350/*%<
351 * Portable front-end to mmap(). If mmap() is not defined on this
352 * platform, then we simulate it by calling malloc() and read().
353 * (In this event, the addr, prot, and flags parameters are ignored).
354 */
355
356int
357isc_file_munmap(void *addr, size_t len);
358/*%<
359 * Portable front-end to munmap(). If munmap() is not defined on
360 * this platform, then we simply free the memory.
361 */
362
363isc_result_t
364isc_file_sanitize(const char *dir, const char *base, const char *ext,
365 char *path, size_t length);
366/*%<
367 * Generate a sanitized filename, such as for MKEYS or NZF files.
368 *
369 * Historically, MKEYS and NZF files used SHA256 hashes of the view
370 * name for the filename; this was to deal with the possibility of
371 * forbidden characters such as "/" being in a view name, and to
372 * avoid problems with case-insensitive file systems.
373 *
374 * Given a basename 'base' and an extension 'ext', this function checks
375 * for the existence of file using the old-style name format in directory
376 * 'dir'. If found, it returns the path to that file. If there is no
377 * file already in place, a new pathname is generated; if the basename
378 * contains any excluded characters, then a truncated SHA256 hash is
379 * used, otherwise the basename is used. The path name is copied
380 * into 'path', which must point to a buffer of at least 'length'
381 * bytes.
382 *
383 * Requires:
384 * - base != NULL
385 * - path != NULL
386 *
387 * Returns:
388 * - ISC_R_SUCCESS on success
389 * - ISC_R_NOSPACE if the resulting path would be longer than 'length'
390 */
391
392bool
393isc_file_isdirwritable(const char *path);
394/*%<
395 * Return true if the path is a directory and is writable
396 */
397
398ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
399
400#endif /* ISC_FILE_H */
